original_title: Interest in Combank stocks enlivens CSE as ASPI crosses 20,000 points for the first time
original_body_lines: The CSE started on a dull note but subsequently brightened up, mostly pushed by interest in banking stocks, especially by a Commercial Bank post interim results announcement yesterday.
Amid those developments, the All Share Price Index crossed 20,000 points for the first time in history.
Provisional data showed the ASPI was up 1.65 percent, or 328.68 points, at 20,257.35, while the S&P SL20 was up 2.14 percent, or 123.68 points, at 5,904.26.

Market turnover was Rs 9.5 billion with fourteen crossings. Top six crossings were reported in LOLC 252,000 shares, crossed to the tune of Rs 142 million; its shares traded at Rs 550, Sampath Bank 850,000 shares crossed to the tune of Rs 119 million; its shares traded at Rs 140,CT Holdings 150,000 shares crossed for Rs 105 million; its shares traded at Rs 700, Singer (SriLanka) 105 million shares crossed to the tune of Rs 104 million; its shares traded at Rs 69, HNB 170,000 shares crossed for Rs 64 million; JKH 2.5 million shares crossed for Rs 57.5 million; its shares traded at Rs 23.

In the retail market companies that mainly contributed to the turnover were; Sierra Cables Rs 659 million (36 million shares traded), HNB Rs 545 million (1.4 million shares traded), Access Engineering Rs 479 million (8.2 million shares traded), Commercial Bank Rs 371 million (2.1 million shares traded), LOLC Rs 328 million (586,000 shares traded), Lanka Venture Engineering Finance Rs 324 million (34 million shares traded) and JKH Rs 254 million (11 million shares traded). During the day 333 million share volumes changed hands in 51764 transactions.
Top contributors to the ASPI were; Commercial Bank up Rs 8.75 at 181.25, DFCC Bank up Rs 7 at 160.25, LOLC Holdings up Rs 29.25 at 581, NTB up Rs 18.75 at 265, and Sampath Bank up Rs 2.25 at 142.50.
Profits at state-run Bank of Ceylon surged 163 percent from a year ago to Rs 18.7 billion, amid strong net interest income growth and trading gains, interim accounts showed.
Profits at Commercial Bank grew 101 percent from a year ago to Rs 15.9 billion in the June 2025 quarter helped by a reduction in loan loss provisions and net interest income growth.
Profits at NDB Bank fell 6 percent from a year ago to Rs 2,447 million in the June 2025 quarter, amid net interest income and fee growth and a decline in fair value gains.
Sampath Bank profits fell 17 percent in the June 2025 quarter to Rs 6.7 billion, due to higher operating expenses.
Profits at NTB grew 11 percent from a year ago to Rs 4.7 billion helped by higher net interest income, and lower provisions.
Profits at HNB, which also has an insurance unit, grew 37 percent from a year ago to Rs 11.74 billion, helped by loan loss reversals and depreciation gains, despite a fall in net interest income.

The rupee opened at Rs 301.25/35 to the US dollar in the spot market yesterday, weaker from Rs 301.05/25 the previous day, while bond yields were broadly steady except for the 2033 tenor, which was down, dealers said.
A bond maturing on 15.12.2028 was quoted at 8.85/95 percent, down from 8.88/97 percent.
A bond maturing on 15.12.2029 was quoted flat at 9.38/42 percent.
A bond maturing on 15.12.2032 was quoted at 10.18/22 percent, down from 10.19/24 percent.
A bond maturing on 01.11.2033 was quoted at 10.60/65 percent.
A bond maturing on 15.09.2034 was quoted at 10.75/85 percent.
